sp.p: Sfoote George, I know not what to say toot, coniure? I shall be hangd ere I coniute.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Nay tell not me of that Captaine, youle nere coniure after your hangd, I warrant you looke you • ir, a parlous matter? sure, first to spred your circle vpon the ground, then with a little coniuring ceremonie, as Ile haue an Hackney-mans wand siluerd ore a purpose for you, then a • riuing in the circle, with a huge word, and a great t • mple as for instance: haue you neuer seene a stalking-stamping Player, that will raise a tempest with his toung, and thunder with his heeles?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: O yes, yes, yes: often, often.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Why be like such a one, for any thing will blea • e the old Knights eyes, for you must note that heele nere dare to venture into the roome, onely perhaps peepe fearefully through the Key hole, to see how the Play goes forward.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well I may goe about it when I will, but marke the end o • t, I shall but shame my selfe ifaith George, speake big words, and stampe and stare and he looke in at Key-hole, why the very thought of that would make me laugh out-right, and spoile all, nay Ile tell thee George, when I apprehend a thing once, I am of such a laxatiue laughter, that if the Deuill him-selfe stood by, I should laugh in his face.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Puh, thats but the babe of a man, and may easily bee husht, as to thinke vpon some disaster, some sad misfortune, as the death of thy Father ithe Country!

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sfoote that would be the more to driue me into such an extasie, that I should nere lin laughing.

sp.speaker: Pib.
sp.p: Why then thinke vpon going to hanging else.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Masse that's well remembred, now ile do well I warrant thee, nere feare me now: but how shall I do George for boysterous words, and horrible names.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Puh, any fustian inuocations Captaine will serue as well as the best, so you rant them out well, or you may goe to a Pothecaries shop, and take all the words from the Boxes.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Troth and you say true George, there's strange words enow to raise a hundred Quack-saluers; tho they be nere so poore when they begin? but here lyes the feare on't, how in this false coniuration a true Deuill should pop vp indeed.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: A true Deuill, Captaine, why there was nere such a one, nay faith hee that has this place, is as false a Knaue as our last Church-warden.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Then hees false inough a conscience ifaith George.

sp.speaker: Crie prisoners.
sp.l: Good Gentlemen ouer the way, send your reliefe,
Good Gentlemen ouer the way,—Good s • r Godfrey?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Hees come, hees come.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Maister, thats my Kinsman younder in the Buff-Ierkin— Kinsman, thats my Maister yonder ith' Taffetie Hatt—pray salute him intirely?

div.stage: They salute: and Py-boord salutes Ma • ster Edmond.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Now my friend.

sp.speaker: Pib.
sp.p: May I pertake your name sir.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p:
My name is Maister
• dm •• d.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Maister Edmond—are you not a Welchman sir?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: A Welshman, why?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Because Maister is your Christen name, and Edmond your sir name?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: O no; I haue more names at home, Maister Edmund Pius, is my full name at length.

sp.speaker: P • b.
sp.p: O crie you mercy 〈◊〉 ?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I vnderstand that you are my Kinsmans good Maister, and in regard of that, the best of my skill is at your seruice: but had you fortunde a • eere stranger, and made no meanes to me by acquaintance, I should haue vtterly denyed to haue beene the man; both by reason of the Act past in Parliament against Coniurers and Witches, as also, because I would not haue my Arte vulgar, trite, and common.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: I much commend your care therein good Captaine Coniurer, and that I will be sure to haue it priuate enough, you shall doote in my Sisters house,—mine owne house I may call it, for both our charges therein are proportiond.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Very good sir—what may I call your losse sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O you may call't a great losse sir, a grieuous losse sir, as goodly a Chaine of gold, tho I say it, that wore it: how saiest thou Nichol • s?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: O 'twas as delicious a Chaine a Gold, Kinsman you know, —

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: You know? did you know't Captaine?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Trust a foole with secrets? — Sir hee may say I know: his meaning is, because my Arte is such, that by it I may gather a knowledge of all things.—

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: I very true.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A pax of all fooles—the excuse stucke vpon my toung like Ship-pitch vpon • Mariners gowne, not to come off in hast—ber-lady Knight to loose such a faire Chaine a gold, were a soule losse; Well, I can put you in this good comfort on't, if it bee betweene Heauen and Earth Knight, Ile ha't for you?

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: A wonderfull Coniuter,—O I, tis betweene heauen and earth I warrant you, it cannot goe out of the realme,— I know tis some-where aboue the earth?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I nigher the earth then thou worst on.

sp.speaker: Sir Goaf.
sp.p: For first my Chaine was rich, and no rich thing shall enter into heauen you know?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: And as for the Deuill Maister, he has no need on't, for you know he ha's a great chaine of his owne?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Thou saiest true Nicholas, but hee has put off that now, that lyes by him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Faith Knight in few wordes, I presume so much vpon the power of my Art; that I could warrant your Chaine againe.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O da • ntie Captaine?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Marry it will cost me much sweat • e, I were better goe to sixteene whot-houses.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: I good man, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Beside great vexation of Kidney and Liuer.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: O twill tickle you here • abouts Coozen, because you haue not beene vsde toot.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: No, haue you not beene vsd too't Captaine?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Plague of all 〈…〉 —indeed Knight I haue 〈◊〉
vsde it a good while, and therefore twill strai • e me so much the more you know.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: On it will, it will.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What plunges hee puts me to, were not this Knight a foole, I had beene twice spoyld now; that Captay • es wo • se then accurst that has an asse to his Kinsman—Sfoote I feare hee will driuell't out before I come toote.—Now sir—to come to the poynt in deede—you see I sticke here in the iawe of the Marshalsea, and cannot doo't.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Tut tur I now thy meaning, thou wouldst say thou'rt a prisoner, I tell thee thou'rt none.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: How none? why is not this the Marshialsea?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: woult heare me speake, I hard of thy rare cuniuring My chayne was lost, I sweate for thy release, As thou shalt doe the like at home for me, Keeper.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Speake is not this man free?

sp.speaker: Keep
sp.p: Yes at his pleasure sir, the fee's dischargd;

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Goe, goe, Ile discharge them I.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I thanke your worship

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Now trust me yar a deere Knight kindnes vnexpected, oh theirs nothing to a free Gentle man.—I will cuniute for you sir till Froath come through my Buffe-ierkin?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Nay then thou shalt not passe with so little a bounty, for at the first sight of my chaine agen,—Forty fine Angells shall appeare vnto thee.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Twill be a glorious showe, ifaith Knight a very fine show, but are all these of your owne house? are you sure of that fir?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: I, I, no, no, whats he younder? talking with my wild Nephew, pray heauen, he giue him good counsell;

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Who he hee's a rare friend of mine, an admirable fellow Knight, the finest fortune-teller.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p:
Oh tis he indeed that came to my Lady sister, & foretold the losse of my chaine, I am not angry with him now, for I see twas my fortune to loose it; by your leaue M. Fortune-teller, I had a glimps on you at home at my Sisters the Widdowes, there you prouisied of the losse of a chaine, — simply tho I stand
here I was he that lost it.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Was it you sir?

sp.speaker: Edn.
sp.p: A my troth Nunckle, hee's the rarest fellow, has told me my fortune so right; I find it so right to my nature.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: What ist? God send it a good one?

sp.speaker: Ed • n.
sp.p: O tis a passing good one, Nuncle: for he sayes I shall proue such an excelent gamster in my time, that I shall spend al faster then my father got it,

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: T'here • s a fortune in deed,

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Nay it hits my humour so pat.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: I that will be the end ont. will the Curse of the beggar preuaile so much, that the sonne shall consume that foolishlie, which the father got, craftilie, I, I, I, twill, twill, twill.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Stay, stay, stay

div.stage: Pyebo • rd with an Almanack and the Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: turne ouer George.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p:
〈◊〉
Iutie, here Iulie thats this month, Sunday thirteene, yester day forteene, to day fifteene.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Looke quickly for the fifteene day,—if within the compasse of these two dayes there would be some Boystrous storme or other, it would be the best, Ide defer him off till then, some tempest and it be thy will?

sp.speaker: Pie
sp.p: Heres the fifteene day—hot and fayre.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Puh, would t'ad beene hot and foule.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: The sixteene day, thats to morrow, the morning for the most part faire and pleasant.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: No lucke.

sp.speaker: Pie
sp.p: But about hye-none-lighning and thunder.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Lighning and thunder, admirable, best of all, Ile coniure to morrow iust at hie none George.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Happen but true to morrow Almanack, and ile giue thee leaue to lie all the yeare after.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: sir I must craue your patience, to bestowe this day vpon me, that I may furnish my selfe strongly,—I sent a spirit into Lanck • shire tother day, to fetch backe a knaue Drouer, and I looke for his returne this euening—to morrow morning my friend here and I will come and breake-fast with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Oh you shall be both most welcome.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: And about Noone without fayle, I purpose to coniure.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Mid noone will be a fine time for you.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Coniuting, do you meane to coniure at our house to morrow sir?

sp.speaker: Cap
sp.p: Many do I sir • t is my intent yong Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p:
〈◊〉 troth, Ile loue you while I liue sort, o rare, Nicholas we sna ••
〈◊〉 coniuring, to morrowe,

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Puh I, I could ha tould you of that.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Law hee could ha told him of that, foole, cockscombe could yee.

sp.speaker: Edm
sp.p: Do you heare me sir, I desire more acquaintance on you, you shall earne some money of me, now I knowe you can coni • re, but can you fetch any that is lost?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Oh any thing thats lost.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Why looke you sir, I tel't you as a frend and a Coniurer, I should marry a Poticaries daughter and twas told me she lost her maiden head at Stonie-statford; now if youle do but so much as conure fort, and make all whole agen.—

sp.speaker: Cap
sp.p: That I will sir.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: By my troth I thanke you la,

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: A litle merry with your sisters sonne sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Oh a simple yong man, very simple, come Captaine, and you sir, weele een part with a gallon of wine till to morrow breake-fast.

sp.speaker: Tip. Cap.
sp.p: Troth agreed sir.

sp.speaker: Nic
sp.p: kinsman—Scholler?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Why now thou art a good Knaue, worth a hundred Brownists.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Am I indeed la: I thanke you truely la.

div.head: Actus. 4.
div.stage: Enter Moll, and Sir Iohn Penny-dub.

sp.speaker: Penne.
sp.p: But I hope you will not serue a Knight so: Gentlewoman will you: to casheere him, and cast him off at your pleasure; what do you thinke I was dubd for nothing, no by my faith Ladies daughter.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Pray Sir Iohn Pennydub, let it be deferd awhile, I haue as bigge a heart to marry as you can haue; but as the Fortuneteler tolld me.

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p:
I ax a'th Fortune-teller, would Derecke had beene
his fortune seauen yeare agoe, to crosse my loue them: did hee know what case I was in, why this is able to make a man drowne himselfe in's Fathers fish-pond.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: And then hee told mee more-ouer Sir Iohn, that the breach of it, kept my Father in Purgatorie.

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: In Purgatorie? why let him purge out his heart there, what haue we to do with that? there's Phisitions enow there to cast his water, is that any matter to vs: how can hee hinder our loue, why let him bew changd now hee's dead?—Well, haue I rid poste day and night, to bring you merry newes of my fathers death, and now—

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Thy Fathers death? is the old Farmer dead?

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: As dead as his Barne doore Moll.

sp.speaker: Moll,
sp.p: And you'le keepe your word with mee now, Sir Iohn. that I shall haue my Coach and my Coach-man?

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: I faith.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: And two white Horses with black Fethers to draw it?

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: Too,

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: A guarded Lackey to run befor't, and pyed liueries to come trashing after't.

sp.speaker: 〈◊〉 Penny.
sp.p: Thou shalt Moll.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: And to let me haue money in my purse to go whether I will.

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: All this.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Then come, what so ere comes on't, weele bee made sure together before the Maides a'the Kitchin.

div.stage: Enter Widdow, with her eldest Daughter Franck and Frailtie.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How now? where's my Brother Sir Godfrey? went hee forth this morning?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O no Madame, hee's aboue at breake-fast, with sir reuerence a Coniurer.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A Coniurer? what manner a fellow is he?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Oh, a wondrous ra • e fellow Mistris, very strongly made vpward, for he goes in a Buff-ierkin: he sayes hee will fetch Sir Godfreys Chaine agen, if it hang betweene heauen and earth.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
What he will not? then hee's an exlent fellow I warrant. how happy were that woman to be blest with such a Husband, a man a cunning? how do's hee looke Frailtie: very swartlie I
warrant, with black beard, scorcht cheekes, and smokie eyebrowes.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p:
Fooh—hee's neither smoake-dryed, nor scorcht, nor black, nor nothing, I tell you Madame, hee lookes as faire to see to, as one of vs; I do not thinke but if you saw him once, you d •
take him to be a Christian.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: So faire, and yet so cunning, that's to bee wonderd at Mother.

div.stage: Enter Sir Oliuer Muck-hill, and Sir Andrew Tip-staf • e.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Blesse you sweete Lady.

sp.speaker: Tip
sp.p: And you faire Mistrisse.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Coades? what doe you meane Gentlemen? fie, did I not giue you your answeres?

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Sweete Lady?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Well, I will not stick with you now for a kisse,
Daughter kisse the Gentleman for once.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yes for • ooth.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.p: Ime proud of such a fauour.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Truly la, sir Oliuer, y are much to blame to come agen, when you know my minde, so well deliuerd — as a Widdow could deliuer a thing.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: But I expect a farther comfort Lady.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why la you now, did I not desire you to put off your sute quite & cleane, when you came to me againe, how say you did I not▪

sp.speaker: Muc.
sp.p: But the sincere loue which my heart beares you,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Go to, ile cut you off. & Sir Oliuer to put you in comfort a farre off, my fortune is read me, I must marry againe.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: O blest fortune!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But not as long as I can choose;—nay Ile hold out, well.

sp.speaker: Muc.
sp.p: Yet are my hopes now fairer.

sp.speaker: Frail
sp.p: O Madam Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How now, what's the hast?

sp.speaker: Tipst.
sp.p: Faith Mistrisse Francis Ile maintaine you gallantly. Ile bring you to Court, weane you among the faire society of ladies poore Kinswomé of mine in cloth of siluer, beside you shall haue your Monckie, your Parrat, your Muskat, & your pisse, pisse, pisse.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: It will do very well.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
What dos he meane to coniure here the? how shall I do to
bee tid of these Knights,—please you Gentlemen to walke a while ith Garden, go gather a pinck, or a Iilly-flower.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: With all our hearts Lady, and count vs fauourd?

sp.speaker: Si. Go.
sp.p: Step in Nicholas, looke, is the coast cleare.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh, as cleare as a Cattes eye, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Go.
sp.p: Then enter Captaine Conisurer?—now—how like you your Roome su?

div.stage: Enter Sir Godf. Capt. Pyb. Edm. Nick.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: O wonderfull conuenient.

sp.speaker: Ed •• .
sp.p: I can tell you Captaine, simplie tho it lies here, tis the fayrest Roome in my Mothers house, as dainty a Roome to Coniute in, mee thinkes,—why you may bidde, I cannot tell how many diuills welcome in't; my Father has had twentie here at once!

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: What diuills?

sp.speaker: Edn.
sp.p: Diuills, no Deputies, & the welthiest men he could get.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Nay put by your chattes now, fall to your businesse roundly, the seskewe of the Diall is vpon the Chrisse-crosse of Noone, but oh: heare met Captaine, a qualme comes ore my stomack?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Oh, how if the diuill should proue a knaue, and teare the hangings.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Fuh, I warrant you Sir Godfrey:

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I Nuncle, or spit fire vpp'oth feeling!

sp.speaker: Sir Godf
sp.p: Very true too, for tis but thin playsterd, and twill quickly take hold a the laths, and if hee chance to spit downeward-too, he will burne all the boords.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: My life for yours Sir Godfrey?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: My Sister is very curious & dainty ore this Roome I can tell and therefore if he must needes spit, I pray desire him to spit ith Chimney.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Why assure you Sir Godfrey, he shall not be brought vp, with so little manners to spit and spaule a'th flower.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Why I thanke you good Captai • e, pray haue a care I, fall to your Circle, weele not trouble you I warrant you, come, weele in to the next Roome, & because we • le be sure to keepe him out there, weele bar vp the dore with some of the Godlies zealous workes.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: That will bee a fine deuice Nuncle, and because the ground shall be as holy as the doore, Ile teare two or three refaires in peices, and strew the leaues about the Chamber? oh, the deuill already,—runs in—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Sfoote Captaine speak somwhat for shame; it lightens & thunders before thou wilt begin, why when?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Pray peace George,—thou'lt make mee laugh anon; and spoile all.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Oh now it begins agen, now, now? now? Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Rumbos-ragdayon, pur, pur, colucundrion, Hois—Plois.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Oh admirable Coniurer? has fetcht Thunder already:

div.stage: Sir Godfrey through the keyhole? within.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Harke harke agen Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Beniamino,—gaspois—kay — gosgothoteron—umbrois.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Oh, I would the deuill would come away quicklie, he has no conscience to put a man to such paine?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Agen!

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Flowste—Kakop •• pos—dragone—Leloomenos—hodge—podge.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Well sayd Captaine.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: So long a comming? oh would I had ner • begun't now, for I feare mee these roaring tempests, will destroy all the fruites of the earth, and tread vpon my come—oh, ith Country.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Gog de gog, hobgoblin, huncks, houseslow, hockley te coome parke.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O brother, brother, what a tempests ith, Garden, sure there's some coniuration abroad.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Tis at home sister!

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: By and by, Ile step in? Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Nunck—Nunck—Rip—Gascoynes, Ipis, Drip—Dropite.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Hee drippes and droppes poore man? alasse, alasse.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Now I come?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: O Sulphure Scoteface—

sp.speaker: Pie
sp.p: Arch-coniurer, what wouldst thou with me?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.l: O the diuill sister, ith dyning Chamber, sing Sister,
I warrant you that will keepe him out, quickly, quickly, quickly. goes in.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p:
So, so, so, Ile release thee, ynough Captaine, ynough,
allowe vs some time to laughe a little, they're shuddering and shaking by this time, as if an Earth-quake were in their kidneyes.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sirrah George, how wast, how wast, did I doo't well ynough.

sp.speaker: Pit.
sp.p: woult beleeue mee Captaine, better then any Coniurer, for here was no harme in this, and yet their horrible expectation satisffied well, you were much beholding to thunder & lightning at this time it gra • st you well I can tell you?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I must needes say so George? sirrah if wee could ha conuoide hether cleanly a cracker or a fire-wheele t'ad beene admitable.

sp.speaker: Pit.
sp.p: Blutt, blutt theirs nothing remaines to put thee to paine now Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Paine? I protest George my heeles are sorer, then a Whitson Morris-dancer.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: All's past now,—oncly to reueale that the chaines ith
Garden where thou knowst it has laine these two daies.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: But I feare that fox Nicholas has reueald it already?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Feare not Captaine, you must put it to'th venture now
Nay tis time, call vpon e'm, take pitty on e'm, for I beleeue
some off 'em are in a pittifull case by this time.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sir Godfrey? Nicholas, Kinsman-Sfoot they'r fast at it still George, Sir Godfrey?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Oh, is that the diuils voyce? how comes he to know my name.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Feare not Sir Godfrey all's quieted.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: What is he layd?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Layde; and has newly dropt, Your chaine ith Garden.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Ith Garden! in our Garden?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Your Garden?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O sweete Coniurer? where abouts there?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Looke-well about a banck of Rosemary.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Sister the Rosemary banck, come, come, ther's my chaine he saies.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh happinesse, run, run.

sp.speaker: Edn.
sp.p: Captaine Coniurer?

div.stage: supposed to goe. Ed • at keyhoole.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Who? Maister Edmond.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I Maister Edmond may I come in safely, without danger thinke you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I uh long agoe, tis all, as twas at first.
Feare nothing, pray come neere—how now? man.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Oh this Roomes mightily hot ifaith, slid my shirt sticks to my Belly already, what a steame the Rogue has left be hind him' foh this roome must be ayrd Gentlemen it sinells horribly of Brimstoone — lets open the windowes.

sp.speaker: Pye
sp.p: Faith ma • ster Edmond tis but your conceite,

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I would you could make me beleeue that ifaith why do you thinke I cannot smell his sauour, from another: yet I take it kindly from you, because you would not put me in a feare ifaith, a my troth I shall loue you for this the lōgest day of my life.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Puh, tis nothing sir, loue me when you see more.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Masse now I remember Ile looke whether he has singed the hangings or no.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Captaine, to entertaine a litle sport till they come; make him bele • ue, youle charme him inuisible, hes apt to admire any thing you see let me alone to giue force too'te.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: goe, retire, to yonder end then.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I protest you are a rare fellowe, are you not.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: O maister Edmond, you know but the least part of me yet, why now at this instant I could but florish my wand thrice ore your head, and charme you inusib'e.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: What you could not? make me walke inuisible man; I should laugh at that ifaith, troth ile requite your kindnes and youle doo't good Captaine coniurer.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Nay I should hardly deny you such a small • indnesse Master Edmond Plus, why looke you sir tis no more but this and thus and agen and now yar inuisible!

sp.speaker: Edm'
sp.p: Am I faith, who would thinke it.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: You see the fortune-teller yonder at farder end ath chamber goe toward him, do what you will with him he shall nere finde you.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Say you so, ile trie that ifaith,—

sp.speaker: Pi • .
sp.p: How now? Captaine, whose that iustled me?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Iustled you? I saw no body.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,—say twas a spirit,

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Shall I • —may be some spirit that haunts the circle.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: O my nose, agen, pray coniur • then Captaine.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Troth this is exlent, I may do any knauery now and neuer be seene, and now I remember mee, Sir Godfrey my Vncle abusde me tother day, & told tales of me to my Mother—Troth now Ime inuisible, ile hit him a sound wherrit ath' eare, when he comes out ath' garden,—I may be reuengd on him now finely.

div.stage: Enter Sir Godfrey, Widdow, Franck, Nicholas with the Chaine.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.l: I haue my Chaine againe, my Chaine's found againe,
O sweete Captaine, O admirable Coniurer. Edm. Strikes him.
Oh what meane you by that Nephew?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Nephew? I hope you do not know mee Vncle?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why did you strike your Vncle sir?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Why Captaine am I not inuisible?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: A goodiest Georg:,—not now you are not Sir,
Why • id you not see me when I did vn channe you?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Not I by my troth Captaine:
Then pray you pardon mee Vncle,
I thought Ide beene inuisible when I struck you.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.l: So. you would doo't? go,—y'are a foolish Boy,
And were I not ore-come with greater ioy,
Ide make you taste correction.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Correction, push—no, neither you nor my Mother shall thinke to whip me as you haue done.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Captaine my ioy is such, I know not how to thanke you, let me embrace you, hug you, O my sweete Chaine, Gladnesse 'een makes mee giddy, rare man: twas as iust ith' Rosemarie bauck, as if one should ha laide it there—oh cunning, cunning!

sp.speaker: W • d.
sp.p:
Well, seeing my fortune tels mee I must marry; let me marry a man of witte a man of parts, here's a worthy Captaine, and 'tis a fine Title truely 〈◊〉 to bee a Captaines Wife, a Captaines Wife, it goes very finely. beside all the world knows that a worthy Captaine, is a fitte Companion to any Lord,
then why not a sweete bed-fellow for any Lady.—Ile haue it so—

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O Mistris, Gentlemen, there's the brauest sight comming along this way.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What braue sight?

sp.speaker: Frai.
sp.p: Oh, one going to burying, & another going to hanging.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A ruefull sight.

sp.speaker: Pyb
sp.p: Sfoot Captaine, Ile pawne my life the Corporals coffind, and old Skirmish the souldier going to execution, & 'tis now full about the time of his walking; hold out a little longer sleepie potion, and we shall haue exlent admiration; for Ile take vpon me the cure of him.

div.stage: Enter the Coffin of the Corporall, the souldier bound, and lead by Officers, the Sheriffe there.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Oh here they come, here they come!

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Now must I close secretly with the Souldier, preuent his impatience, or else all's discouered?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O lamentable seeing, these were those Brothers, that sought and bled before our doore.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: What they were not Sister?

sp.speaker: Ski • m.
sp.p: George, looke toote, Ile peach at Tyburne else.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Mum,—Gentles all, vouchsafe mee audience, and you especially Maister S •• iffe:
sp.l: Yon man is bound to 〈◊〉 ,
Because he wounded this that now lyes coffind?

sp.speaker: Shir.
sp.p: True, true, he shall haue the law,—and I know the law?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: But vnder • auour Maister Sheriffe, if this man had beene cured and safe agen, he should haue been releasde then?

sp.speaker: Shir.
sp.p: Why make you question of that Sir?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Then I release him freely, and will take vpon mee the death that he should dye, if within a little season, I do not cure him to his proper health agen.

sp.speaker: Shir.
sp.l: How Sir? recouer a dead man?
That were most strange of all.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sweete Sir, I loue you deerely, and could wish my best part yours, — oh do not vndertake such an impossible venture.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: Loue you me; then for your sweet sake Ile doo't:
Let me entreate the corps to be set downe.

sp.speaker: Shir.
sp.p: Bearers set downe the Coffln,—this were wonderfull, and worthy Stoes Chronicle.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: I pray bestow the freedome of the ayre, vpon our wholsome Arte, — masse, his cheekes begin to receiue naturall warmth: nay good Corporall wake betime, or I shall haue a longer sleepe then you,—Sfoote if he should proue dead indeed now, he were fully reuengd vpon me for making a property on him, yet I had rather run vpon the Ropes, then haue the Rope like a Tetter run vpon mee, oh—he stirs—hee stirs agen—looke Gentlemen, he recouers, he starts, he rises.

sp.speaker: Shir.
sp.p: Oh, oh, defend vs—out alasse.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Nay pray be still; youle make him more giddy else, — he knowes no body yet.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: Zounes: who am I? couerd with Snow? I maruaile?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Nay I knew hee would sweare the first thing hee did, as soone as euer he came to his life agen.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: Sfoote Hostesse—some hotte Porridge,—oh, oh, lay on a dozen of Fagots in the Moone parler, there.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Lady, you must needs take a little pitty of him yfaith, and send him in to your Kitchin fire.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh, with all my heart sir, Nicholas and Frailtie, he'pe to beare him in.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Beare him in, qua tha, pray call out the Maides, I shall nere haue the heart to doo't indeed la.

sp.speaker: Frai.
sp.p: Not I neither, I cannot abide to handle a Ghost of all me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Shloud, let me see, where was I drunke last night, heh—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh, shall I bid you once agen take him away.

sp.speaker: Frai.
sp.p: Why, we're as fearefull as you I warrant you—oh—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Away villaines, bid the Maides make him a Cawdle p • esently to settle his braine,—or a Posset of Sack, quickly, quickly.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Sir, what so ere you are, I do more then admire you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O I, if you knew all Maister Shiriffe, as you shall doe, you would say then, that here were two of the rarest men within the walls of Christendome

sp.speaker: Shir.
sp.p: Two of'em, O wonderfull: Officers I discharge you, set him free all's in tune.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: I and a banquet ready by this time Maister Sheriffe, to which I most cheerefully enuite you, and your late prisoner there? see you this goodly chaine sir, mun, no more words, twas lost, a dis found againe; come my inestimable bullies, weele talke of your noble Acts in sparkling Charnico, and in stead of a Iester, weele ha the ghost ith white sheete sit at vpper end a'th Table.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.p: Exlent merry man yfaith.

sp.speaker: Franck
sp.l: Well, seeing I am enioynd to loue and marry.
My foolish vow thus I casheere to Ayre
Which first begot it,—now loue play thy part;
The scholler reades his lecture in my heart.

div.head: Actus 5. Scen. 1.
div.stage: Enter in hast Maister Edmund and Frayltie.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: This is the marriage morning for my mother & my sister.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O me Maister Edmund we shall ha rare doings.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: Nay go Frayltie runne to the Sexton, you know my mother wilbe married at Saint Antlings, hie thee, tis past fiue, bid them open the Church dore, my sister is almost ready.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: What al ready Maister Edmond.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: Nay go hie thee first run to the Sexton, and runne to the Clarke and then run to Maister Pigman the Parson, and then run to the Millanor, and the • run home agen.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Heer's run, run, run—

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: But harke Frailty:

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: What more yet?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Has the maides remembred to strew the way to the Church.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Fagh an houre ago I help 'em my selfe.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: Away, away, away, away then.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Away, away, away then

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p:
I shall haue a simple Father inlawe, a braue Captaine able to beate all our streete: Captaine Idle, now my Ladie Mother wilbe • itted for a delicate name, my Ladie Idle, my Lalie Idle, the finest name that can be for a woman, and then the Scholler Maister Pie-boord for my sister Francis, that wilbe
Mistris Francis Pie-bo • rd, Mistris Francis Pie-boord, theill keepe a good table I warrant you, Now all the knights noses are put out of ioynt, they may go to a bone setters now. Enter Captaine and Pie-boord. Harke, harke oh who comes here with two Torches before 'em, my sweete Captaine, and my fine Scholler, oh, how brauely they are shot vp in one night, they looke like fine Brittaines now me thinkes, heres a gallant chaunge ifaith slid they haue hir'd men and all by the clock.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Maister Edmund, kinde, honest, dainty Maister Edmond.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Fogh, sweete Captaine Father inlaw a rare perfume isayth.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: What are the Brides stirring? may wee steall vpon 'em thinkst thou Maister Edmond.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Faw, there e'en vpon red dines I can assure you? for they were at there Totch e'en now, by the same token I tumbled downe the staires.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Alas poore Maister Edmond.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: O the musitians I prce the Maister Edmond call' em in and licquour 'em a little.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: That I will sweete Captaine father in law and make ech of them as drunck as a common fiddeler.

div.stage: Eneter Sir Iohn Penidub, and Moll aboue lacing of her clothes.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Whewh Mistris Mol, Mistris Mol.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Who Sir Iohn Penidub O you'r an early cocke ifayth, who would haue thought you to be so rare a stirrer.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Pree the Mol let me come vp.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: No by my faith Sir Iohn, Ile keepe you downe, for you Knights are very dangerous if once you get aboue.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Ile not stay ifaith.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p:
Ifaith you shall staie, for Sir Iohn you must note the nature of the Climates your Northen wench in her owne Countrie may well hold out till shee bee fifteene,
but if she touch the South once, and vp to London, here the Chimes go presently after twelue.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: O th' art a mad wench Moll, but I pree thee make hast, for the Priest is gone before.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Do you follow him, Ile not be long after.

div.stage: Enter Sir Oliuer Muck-hill, Sir Andrew Tip-staffe, and old Skirmish talking.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: O monstrous vn-heard of forge • ie.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.p: Knight, I neuer heard of such villany in our owne countrie, in my life.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Why 'tis impossible, dare you maintaine your words?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Dare wee? een to their wezen pipe;, we know all their plots, they cannot squander with vs, they haue knauishly abusd vs, made onely properties on's to aduance their selues vpon our shoulders, but they shall rue their abuses, this morning they are to bee married.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Tis too true, yet if the Widdow be not too much besotted on slights and forgeries, the reue'ation of their villanies will make 'em loathsome, and to that end, be it in priuate to you, I sent late last night to an honourable personage, to whom I am much indebted in kindnesse, as he is to me, and therefore presume vpon the paiment of his tongue, and that hee will lay out good words for me, and to speake truth, for such needfull occasions, I onely preserue him in bond, and some-times he may doe mee more good here in the Cittie by a free word of his mouth, then if hee had paide one halfe in hand, and tooke Doomesday for t' other.

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.p: In troth Sir, without soothing bee it spoken, you haue publisht much iudgement in these few words.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: For you know, what such a man vtters will be thought effectuall and to waighty purpose, and therefore into his mouth weel put the approoued theame of their forgeries.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: And Ile maintaine it Knight, if sheele be true.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: How now fellow.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: May it please you Sir, my Lord is newly lighted from his Coache.

sp.speaker: Muc.
sp.l: Is my Lord come already; his honnours early,
You see he loues me well vp before seauen,
Trust me I haue found him night capt at a eleuen,
Ther's good hope yet; come Iee relate all to him.

div.stage: Enter the two Bridegromes Captaine and Scholler after them, Sir Godsrey and Edmond, Widdow change in apparell, mistris Francis led betweene two Knights, Sir Iohn Penny-dub and

sp.speaker: Moll:
sp.p:
there meetes them a Noble man, Sir Oliuer Muckil,
•• d Sir Andrew Tip-staffe.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: By your leaue Lady.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: My Lord your honour is most chastly welcome,

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Madam tho I came now from court, I come not to flatter you: vpon whom can I iustly cast this blot, but vpon your owne fore-head, that know not inke from milke such is the blind besotting in the state of an vnheaded woman thats a widdow. For it is the property of all you that are widdowes (a hand full excepted) to hate those that honestly and carefully loue you, to the maintenance of credit state and posterity, and strongly to doat on those, that only loue you to vndo you who regard you least are best regarded, who hate you most are best beloued, And if there be but one man amongst tenne thousand millions of men that is accurst disastrous and euilly planeted whome Fortune beates most, whome God hates most, and all Societies esteeme least, that man is suere to be a husband — Such is the peeuish Moone that rules you bloods. An Impudent fellow best woes you, a flattering lip best wins you, or in a mirth who talkes roughliest is most sweetest, nor can you distinguish truth, from forgeries, mistes from Simplisity, witnes those two deceitfull monsters that you haue entertaind for bride-groomes.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Deceitfull.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: All will out.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sfoote who has blabd George? that foolish Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: For what they haue besotted you easie blood withall, weare nought but forgeries, the fortune telling for husbands, the coniuring for the chaine, Sir Godfrey heard the falshod of al: nothing but meere knauery deceit and eoozenage.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
O wonderfull, indeed I wondred that my husband with
all his crast could nor keepe himselfe out of purgatory.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: And I more wonder that my chaine should be gon and my Taylor had none of it.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: And I wondred most of all that I, should be tyed from marriage hauing such a mind too't, come S. Iohn Pennydub, faire wether on our side the moone has chaingd since yester night.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: The Sting of euery euill is with-in mee.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: And that you may perceaue I faine not with you, behould their fellow actor in those forgeries who full of Spleene and enuy at their so suddaine aduancements reueled all there plot in anger.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Base Souldier to reueall vs.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ist possible wee should be blinded so and our eys open

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Widdow wil you now beleeue that false, which to soone you beleeued true.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O to my shame I doe.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: But vnder fauour my Lord my chaine was truely lost and straingly found againe.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Resolue him of that Souldier,

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: In few words Knight then, thou wert the arch-gull of all.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: God How Sir.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Nay ile proue it: for the chayne was but hid in the rosemary bancke all this while, and thou gotst him out of pryson to Conture for it who did it admirably fustianly, for indeed what neede any others when he knew where it was.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O vilainty of vilanies, but how came my chaine there

sp.speaker: Skir,
sp.p: Wheres truly la, in deed la, he that will not sweare, but lie, he that will not steale, But rob: pure Nicholas Saint Antlings.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.l: O Villaine one of our society,
Deemd alwaies holy, pure, religious,
A Puritan? a theefe, when wast euer hard?
Sooner wee'll kill a man then Steale thou knowst,
Out flane Ile rend my lyon from thy back—with mine owne hands.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Deare Maister, oh.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Nay Knight dwell in patience,
sp.p:
And now widdow being so neere the Church, twer great pitty, nay vncharity to send you home againe without a husband,
drawe nerer you of true worship, state and credit, that should not stand so farre of from a widdow, and suffer forged shapes to come betweene you, Not that in these, I blemish the trne Title of a Captaine, or blot the faire margent of a Scholler; For I honnor worthy and deserning parts in the one, and cherrish fruitfull Vertues in the other. Come Lady, and you Virgin bestowe your eys and your purest affections, vpon me of estimation both in Court and Citry, that hath long woed you, and both with there hearts and wealth sincearly loue you.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Good Sister doe: Sweet little Franke, these are men of reputation, you shalbe welcome at Court: a great creddit for a Cittizen sweet Sister.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Come her scilence doos consent too't.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I know not with what face,

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Pah pah why with your owne face they desire no other.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pardon me worthy Sirs, I and my daughter haue wrongd your lo • es.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.l: Tis easily pardon'd Lady,
If you vouch safe it now.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: With all my soule,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And I with all my heart,

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: And I Sir Iohn with soule, heart, lights and all.

sp.speaker: Sir I oh.
sp.l: They are all mine Moll.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Now Lady?
What honest Spirit but will applaud your choyce,
And gladly furnish you with hand and voyce,
A happy change which makes een heauen reioyce,
Come enter into your loyes, you shall not want,
For fathers now, I doubt it not beleeue me,
But that you shall haue hands inough to giue.
